title: Democrats Schedule Votes on Abortion Access, but Lack a Legislative Path
abstract: Under pressure to act, Democrats have scheduled votes on bills to preserve abortion access. But with Republicans and at least one Democrat opposed, they lack the support to succeed.
des_facet: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)

multimedia.caption: Speaker Nancy Pelosi plans to bring to a vote this week a measure would protect the right to travel for abortion services.
multimedia.copyright: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times

title: States With Abortion Bans Risk Losing Their Economic Edge
abstract: The Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade has prompted Democratic governors to pitch their states as better alternatives for business.
des_facet: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)

multimedia.caption: Gov. J.B. Pritzker of Illinois, a Democrat, urged executives to rethink basing their companies in Texas, which he called “a state that strips its residents of their dignity.”
multimedia.copyright: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times

title: The Right to Travel in a Post-Roe World
abstract: In a concurring opinion last month, Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh said the Constitution did not allow states to stop women from traveling to get abortions. But the issue is more complicated than that.

multimedia.caption: Demonstrators marched to the home of Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh in September. Though some form of a constitutional right to travel is almost uniformly accepted, the Supreme Court has struggled to say exactly where to find it or precisely how to define it.
multimedia.copyright: Tom Brenner for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Demonstrators marched to the home of Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh in September. Though some form of a constitutional right to travel is almost uniformly accepted, the Supreme Court has struggled to say exactly where to find it or precisely how to define it.
multimedia.copyright: Tom Brenner for The New York Times

title: F.D.A. to Weigh Over-the-Counter Sale of Contraceptive Pills
abstract: The first U.S. application for sale of a nonprescription birth control pill has taken on new meaning after the Supreme Court decision ending the constitutional right to abortion.
byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Kate Kelly
des_facet: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)

multimedia.caption: More than six decades after contraceptive pills were approved for use in the United States, they are still not available without a prescription.
multimedia.copyright: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: More than six decades after contraceptive pills were approved for use in the United States, they are still not available without a prescription.

title: Most Democrats Don’t Want Biden in 2024, New Poll Shows
abstract: With the country gripped by a pervasive sense of pessimism, the president is hemorrhaging support.

multimedia.caption: President Biden in Cleveland last week. Only 26 percent of Democratic voters said the party should renominate him in 2024.
President Biden in Cleveland last week. Only 26 percent of Democratic voters said the party should renominate him in 2024.
President Biden in Cleveland last week. Only 26 percent of Democratic voters said the party should renominate him in 2024.

title: Cassidy Hutchinson: Why the Jan. 6 Committee Rushed Her Testimony
abstract: Sequestered with family and security, Ms. Hutchinson, 26, has in the process developed an unlikely bond with Representative Liz Cheney, the panel’s vice chairwoman.
org_facet: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

multimedia.caption: Cassidy Hutchinson, a former aide to President Donald J. Trump’s chief of staff, offered explosive testimony about Mr. Trump last month.
Cassidy Hutchinson, a former aide to President Donald J. Trump’s chief of staff, offered explosive testimony about Mr. Trump last month.

title: Defense Firm Said U.S. Spies Backed Its Bid for Pegasus Spyware Maker
abstract: The American contractor L3Harris is said to have cited support from intelligence officials for its effort to acquire NSO, the Israeli spyware company blacklisted by the Biden administration.
byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Ronen Bergman

multimedia.caption: An NSO office in southern Israel. The Biden administration blacklisted the cyber hacking firm, saying it had acted “contrary to the national security or foreign policy interests of the United States.”

An NSO office in southern Israel. The Biden administration blacklisted the cyber hacking firm, saying it had acted “contrary to the national security or foreign policy interests of the United States.”

title: Bannon, Facing Jail and Fines, Agrees to Testify to Jan. 6 Panel
abstract: Stephen K. Bannon, the former Trump campaign manager and White House adviser, made the abrupt about-face after the former president authorized him to talk to investigators.
byline: By Luke Broadwater and Maggie Haberman
org_facet: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

multimedia.caption: Stephen K. Bannon’s decision to comply with the Jan. 6 committee’s subpoena came after he was cleared to testify by Mr. Trump.
Stephen K. Bannon’s decision to comply with the Jan. 6 committee’s subpoena came after he was cleared to testify by Mr. Trump.

title: Biden Will Find a Changed Middle East on His Coming Visit
abstract: On his first trip to the region since taking office, President Biden will begin in Israel, which has been building relations with Arab nations. He will also make a stop in Saudi Arabia.

multimedia.caption: President Biden arriving at Joint Base Andrews last Wednesday. During his trip to the Middle East, Mr. Biden is expected to discuss the emerging Arab-Israeli military partnership to combat threats from Iran.

President Biden arriving at Joint Base Andrews last Wednesday. During his trip to the Middle East, Mr. Biden is expected to discuss the emerging Arab-Israeli military partnership to combat threats from Iran.

President Biden arriving at Joint Base Andrews last Wednesday. During his trip to the Middle East, Mr. Biden is expected to discuss the emerging Arab-Israeli military partnership to combat threats from Iran.

title: The Fight Over Truth Also Has a Red State, Blue State Divide
abstract: Several states run by Democrats are pushing for stiffer rules on the spread of false information, while Republican-run states are pushing for fewer rules.
byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Cecilia Kang

title: Despite Repeated Fumbles, Georgia Republicans Say They’re Sticking With Walker
abstract: Republicans are standing behind Herschel Walker, the former football star, despite an array of revelations, missteps and questions about his qualifications for a Senate seat.

multimedia.caption: Republican officials and strategists in Georgia said their support for Herschel Walker has not wavered.
multimedia.copyright: Nicole Craine for The New York Times

title: One Small Step for Democracy in a ‘Live Free or Die’ Town
abstract: A cautionary tale from Croydon, N.H., where one man tried to foist a change so drastic it jolted a community out of political indifference.

multimedia.caption: A Croydon town meeting in March that began as fairly routine. It didn’t end that way.
A Croydon town meeting in March that began as fairly routine. It didn’t end that way.
A Croydon town meeting in March that began as fairly routine. It didn’t end that way.

title: At 79, Biden Is Testing the Boundaries of Age and the Presidency
abstract: President Biden has said he plans to run for a second term, but his age has become an uncomfortable issue for him and his party.

multimedia.caption: Just a year and a half into his first term, President Biden is already more than a year older than Ronald Reagan was at the end of two terms.
multimedia.copyright: Tom Brenner for The New York Times

title: Jan. 6 Panel Questions Cipollone on Pardons and Trump’s Election Claims
abstract: Pat A. Cipollone, the former White House counsel for President Donald J. Trump, appeared before the House committee investigating the Capitol attack for roughly eight hours on Friday.
byline: By Luke Broadwater and Maggie Haberman
org_facet: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

multimedia.caption: Pat A. Cipollone, the former White House counsel, during a break in his interview with the Jan. 6 committee on Friday. A spokesman for the panel said it “received critical testimony on nearly every major topic in its investigation.”

Pat A. Cipollone, the former White House counsel, during a break in his interview with the Jan. 6 committee on Friday. A spokesman for the panel said it “received critical testimony on nearly every major topic in its investigation.”

title: Liz Cheney’s Latest Fans: Democratic Donors
abstract: Despite policy disagreements, donors like Jeffrey Katzenberg are backing the Wyoming Republican because of her role on the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack.
byline: By Kate Kelly and Maggie Haberman
org_facet: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

multimedia.caption: Representative Liz Cheney, the vice chairwoman of the Jan. 6 committee, has called former President Donald J. Trump “a domestic threat that we have never faced before.”

title: Fears of Another Gas Shock Drive Biden to Seek Price Cap on Russian Oil
abstract: Negotiating and selling the plan is a crucial task facing Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen as she travels to Asia in hopes of averting $7 a gallon gasoline.

multimedia.caption: Gas prices dipped this past week, but some officials in the Biden administration are worried about another surge.

title: Ukraine and the Contest of Global Stamina
abstract: The conflict’s long-run trajectory seems increasingly likely to be shaped by whether the United States and its allies can maintain their military, political and financial commitments to holding off Russia.
byline: By Peter Baker and David E. Sanger

multimedia.caption: Destroyed cars in Irpin, Ukraine, this month. More than four months into the Russian invasion, the war has evolved into a battle of inches with no end in sight.
multimedia.copyright: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

title: Shinzo Abe’s Influence Was Still Evident Long After He Left Office
abstract: Japan’s longest-serving prime minister became perhaps the most transformational politician in the country’s post-World War II history.

multimedia.caption: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan, who was assassinated on Friday, edged the country closer to the United States and most of its Pacific allies.
Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan, who was assassinated on Friday, edged the country closer to the United States and most of its Pacific allies.

title: At BroadwayCon, Hillary Clinton Celebrates Women in the Theater
abstract: The former secretary of state moderated a discussion on Friday afternoon about successes and barriers for women working in the theater.

multimedia.caption: Hillary Clinton, center, with, from left, LaChanze, Donna Murphy and Vanessa Williams at the Manhattan Center on Friday afternoon.
Hillary Clinton, center, with, from left, LaChanze, Donna Murphy and Vanessa Williams at the Manhattan Center on Friday afternoon.

title: Can Lisa Murkowski Fend Off Kelly Tshibaka in Alaska?
abstract: Supporters of the senator hope that the state’s unique nonpartisan primary system will help her, but allies of Tshibaka, a Trump-backed challenger, see a path to victory.

multimedia.caption: Kelly Tshibaka speaking to supporters in Anchorage. Endorsed by Donald Trump, she is challenging Senator Lisa Murkowski from the right.
multimedia.copyright: Ash Adams for The New York Times

title: Russia Votes to Shut Down Last U.N. Aid Route Into Syria
abstract: Millions of Syrians whose lives have already been shattered by more than a decade of war may be left without food, medicine and other supplies.

multimedia.caption: Refugees from Syria passing through the Bab al-Hawa crossing at the Turkish border into northwest Syria in 2019.
Refugees from Syria passing through the Bab al-Hawa crossing at the Turkish border into northwest Syria in 2019.

title: Putting the Public Back in Public Service
abstract: A group of academics and lawmakers, citing a new study that found voters feel shut out of congressional deliberations, is pushing to engage citizens more directly in the work of Congress.

multimedia.caption: A new study found the public’s low opinion of Congress stems in part from the impression that lawmakers have a poor understanding of constituents’ views.
multimedia.copyright: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times

title: Review Finds Agents Used Unnecessary Force Against Black Migrants
abstract: Four Border Patrol agents face discipline over the confrontation last year. But the 500-page report described deeper problems within the agency amid a crisis at the border.
byline: By Eileen Sullivan and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

multimedia.caption: Border Patrol agents on horseback chased migrants as they tried to cross the southwestern border in September.
Border Patrol agents on horseback chased migrants as they tried to cross the southwestern border in September.
